metadata.title: Automating Personal Investments with Excel and Python | by Lucas Nunes Fernandes | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Automating Personal Investments with Excel and Python
metadata.description: Python Script Personal Investments Automation, based on Pandas and Matplotlib libraries, and Excel file which handles both input and output information.

all_paragraphs: I had been wondering for quite some time how I could develop Python projects since Python isn’t heavily used in my daily work. So, I see here two possible situations which you might fit in:
Either your job does not exactly offer you the programming skills you are looking for or, in fact, it does not offer you any opportunity to use it at all.

Whatever is your case (even one not included in the above), in this post you might find an interesting Python project to start right now. So, what is it anyway? I managed to develop a way you can input the Stocks you own and track each Stock performance in a daily-basis.

First of all, what does the code actually do? Put simply, you must provide 3 inputs regarding each one of the Stocks you own in an Excel file and, then, use the Python Script shared in this post in order to update each one of these Stocks performance, in a daily basis.

Which information is needed to be input in an Excel file? The Stock Transaction Code (“ticker”), the Number of Stocks (“qty”), and the Total Cost (“priceBought”) you had for each Stock. Very simple, right? Besides the fact that these inputs are very straight forward, it’s important to highlight that you need to input them just once.
PS: I’m from Brazil, so I considered an example in which I selected some Stocks from the Brazilian Stock Market.
Without further ado, let’s finally take a look at the code itself.

My goal here is to share the way I structured the analysis and to highlight the things I judge are the most important ones. It’s also important to mention I encourage you to search for any library, methods, or attributes you are not sure how it works.

This is my first post on Medium. The important thing here is to share some useful things which could be done using Python, especially for those who don’t directly work with it but wish to learn more about it. You can adapt this code to plot accumulated balance and to differentiate the day you bought each Stock, for instance. It’s on both your own imagination and necessity.
